about.more_info_en: Ranson's Criteria was developed in the 1970s to address pancreatitis mortality; however, it may over-estimate mortality given its study and development 30-40 years ago. The BISAP Score requires fewer patient variables and is likely just as accurate -- if not moreso -- than Ranson's criteria for predicting adverse outcome in patients with acute pancreatitis.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Ranson JH, Rifkind KM, Roses DF, Fink SD, Eng K, Spencer FC. Prognostic signs and the role of operative management in acute pancreatitis. Surg Gynecol Obstet. 1974 Jul;139(1):69-81. PubMed PMID: 4834279.

creator_info.about_en: John H. C. Ranson, MD, (d. 1995) was a surgeon and director of the division of general surgery at the NYU. He helped improve the treatment of pancreatitis and developed a widely used system for predicting the outcome of pancreatic disease. Dr. Ranson was the co-author of Acute Pancreatitis.

how_to_use.use_case_en: Calculated on admission, and at 48 hours, to estimate mortality from pancreatitis.

next_steps.management_en: Helps determine the disposition of the patient, with a higher score corresponding to a higher level of care.

input_schema.label_en: BUN increase >5 mg/dL (>1.79 mmol/L) from admission
input_schema.name: bun_5

input_schema.label_en: Base deficit (24 - HCO3) >4 mg/dL within 48 hours
input_schema.name: base_deficit_4

medium_description_en: Estimates mortality of patients with pancreatitis, based on initial and 48-hour lab values.
